newsitem.title: UK: British explorer to join Antarctic solo race.
newsitem.headline: British explorer to join Antarctic solo race.

text.p: British explorer Sir Ranulph Fiennes set off from Britain on Tuesday to join a race to become the first man to cross the Antarctic on foot alone and without any material backup.
Fiennes, 53, who aims to raise three million pounds ($4.5 milion) in aid of cancer research, will compete against four others, including Poland's Marek Kaminski.
In 1995, Kaminski became the first person ever to walk to both the North and South poles in a single year.

Two Norwegians and a Swiss will also join in the race across 1,800 miles (3,000 kilometre) of frozen wilderness, which starts on November 1 from Berkner Island, a part of Antarctica which lies off the southern coast of Chile.
Fiennes, a former member of the Special Air Service elite commando unit, will have to drag 500 lb (227 kg) of supplies and equipment on a sledge in temperatures as low as -20C (-4F).
"I can only liken it to towing a legless bathtub filled with three large men over 1,800 miles of sand dunes," Fiennes said.
The journey is expected to take nearly three months.
Fiennes and a companion made a similar trek across Antartica in 1993, during which he lost a third of his bodyweight and nearly lost some toes due to frostbite.
